Rakesh Patel wrote:

> have a bit of an update on my new TDD experiment.
> 
> Apparently it is good practice to use interfaces and provide pluggable
> implementations as needed. I have heard this is good for testing.

Yes, it is.

> So let me explain what I am trying to do. I am building my first web
> services application but sticking with POJOs in the service layer
> initially. I want to create a web service for a postcode lookup servlet
> we already have. This servlet produces XML output but the code to
> connect and send in paramters is all done manually (the author did not
> know about web services at the time).
> 
> So here's my initial design.
> 
> public interface PostcodeService {
>     public String getAddressAsXML(String postcode);
> }
> 
> now, should I write a test class against the
> interface(PostcodeServiceTest) or against the implementation
> class(PostcodeServiceImplTest)?

I never start with an interface. I assume you want to test the behavior 
of the implementation of the Postcode service. In that case, do you even 
need to extract an interface yet? When do you think you'll need the 
interface? Probably when it's time to expose the service as a web 
service. Worry about the interface then. In the meantime, test-drive 
PostcodeService.

> Now calling the underlying postcode servlet actually costs money so I
> know I will need to produce a mock version of it also. So do I create a
> test class for this also(PostcodeServiceMockImpl)?

I'm confused here. Are you /building/ PostcodeService? or using it?

If you're building it, then you'd only fake/mock/substitute it when you 
wanted to test something else that uses PostcodeService. Don't worry 
about it until you get there.

If you're using PostcodeService, then I'm still confused and can't offer 
more advice.

> Thats 3 potential test classes and also they will probably be very
> similar. Is that right? I can also see when I come to code DAOs i will
> be in a similar situation since I will probably want to mock db access
> (perhaps the mock will return hard coded values).

Check out my weblog (diasparsoftware.com/weblog) and look for an entry 
called "When to fake, when to mock." It might help you understand how I 
use those two concepts in interaction testing.

> I am spending way too long thinking about this rather than writing code
> which has me a bit worried.

Test-drive your implementation of PostcodeService. If that 
implementation uses other expensive services, hide those behind 
interfaces and fake/mock them. When you're done, decide whether you need 
to extract an interface from PostcodeService to publish. Does that help?
